[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: MAXIMUM_NUMBER_FILESTORE_THREADS] [Resource Exhaustion] Can an attacker exploit the hardcoded MAXIMUM_NUMBER_FILESTORE_THREADS limit of 10 to cause thread pool exhaustion by creating exactly 10 long-running file store operations, blocking all subsequent indexer operations and causing service unavailability? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: MAXIMUM_NUMBER_FILESTORE_THREADS] [Integer Overflow] Is the MAXIMUM_NUMBER_FILESTORE_THREADS value (10) validated during runtime allocation, or could integer arithmetic operations involving this constant overflow when multiplied with other limits, leading to undefined behavior or security vulnerabilities? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: MAXIMUM_NUMBER_FILESTORE_THREADS] [Configuration Bypass] Can malicious code bypass the MAXIMUM_NUMBER_FILESTORE_THREADS limit by directly spawning threads outside the file store mechanism, circumventing intended resource constraints and causing system instability? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: MAXIMUM_NUMBER_FILESTORE_THREADS] [Race Condition] If multiple components simultaneously check and allocate threads against MAXIMUM_NUMBER_FILESTORE_THREADS, can race conditions allow the actual thread count to exceed 10, violating resource guarantees and potentially crashing the indexer service? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: GRPC_AUTH_TOKEN_HEADER] [Authentication Bypass] Can an attacker bypass authentication by sending requests without the 'x-aptos-data-authorization' header, or by manipulating header case-sensitivity to evade validation checks while still reaching protected endpoints? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: GRPC_AUTH_TOKEN_HEADER] [Header Injection] Can an attacker inject malicious payloads or control characters into the 'x-aptos-data-authorization' header value to exploit downstream parsing logic, causing buffer overflows, command injection, or authentication bypass? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: GRPC_AUTH_TOKEN_HEADER] [Token Leakage] Does the GRPC_AUTH_TOKEN_HEADER constant implementation ensure tokens are properly sanitized from logs and error messages, or can authentication tokens leak through exception traces, metrics, or debug output, exposing credentials? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: GRPC_AUTH_TOKEN_HEADER] [Replay Attack] Can captured 'x-aptos-data-authorization' header values be replayed indefinitely without expiration or nonce validation, allowing attackers to reuse stolen tokens to access the indexer service? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: GRPC_AUTH_TOKEN_HEADER] [Header Confusion] Can an attacker send multiple 'x-aptos-data-authorization' headers in a single request to cause confusion in header parsing logic, potentially bypassing authentication by exploiting first-header vs last-header precedence ambiguities? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: GRPC_REQUEST_NAME_HEADER] [Path Traversal] Can an attacker inject directory traversal sequences (../, ../../) into the 'x-aptos-request-name' header to manipulate data destination paths, potentially overwriting critical system files or accessing unauthorized directories? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: GRPC_REQUEST_NAME_HEADER] [Request Routing Manipulation] Can a malicious client forge the 'x-aptos-request-name' header to redirect indexer data to unintended destinations, causing data corruption, service disruption, or unauthorized data access? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: GRPC_REQUEST_NAME_HEADER] [Resource Naming Collision] Can an attacker craft a request name that collides with internal system resource names, causing the indexer to overwrite or corrupt internal state, metrics, or configuration data? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: GRPC_REQUEST_NAME_HEADER] [SQL/NoSQL Injection] If the request name from 'x-aptos-request-name' is used in database queries without proper sanitization, can attackers inject SQL or NoSQL commands to extract, modify, or delete indexer data? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: GRPC_REQUEST_NAME_HEADER] [Denial of Service] Can an attacker send extremely long or specially crafted request names via 'x-aptos-request-name' to cause buffer overflows, memory exhaustion, or excessive processing time in downstream components? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: GRPC_API_GATEWAY_API_KEY_HEADER] [Authorization Confusion] Can an attacker exploit the difference between GRPC_AUTH_TOKEN_HEADER and GRPC_API_GATEWAY_API_KEY_HEADER to bypass authentication by sending API keys in the wrong header, causing authorization logic to fail open? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: GRPC_API_GATEWAY_API_KEY_HEADER] [API Key Exposure] Does the 'authorization' header (GRPC_API_GATEWAY_API_KEY_HEADER) properly protect API keys from being logged, cached, or stored in plaintext, or can keys leak through observability infrastructure? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: GRPC_API_GATEWAY_API_KEY_HEADER] [Key Format Validation] Is there proper validation of API key format in the 'authorization' header, or can malformed keys cause parsing errors, exceptions, or security bypasses in authentication middleware? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: MESSAGE_SIZE_LIMIT] [Size Limit Bypass] Can an attacker bypass the 15MB MESSAGE_SIZE_LIMIT by sending chunked messages, compressed payloads that expand beyond the limit, or by exploiting integer overflow in size calculations? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: MESSAGE_SIZE_LIMIT] [Compression Bomb] Can an attacker send highly compressible data within the 15MB MESSAGE_SIZE_LIMIT that expands to gigabytes when decompressed, causing decompression bombs and memory exhaustion? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: MESSAGE_SIZE_LIMIT] [Integer Overflow in Size Check] Can the MESSAGE_SIZE_LIMIT constant (1024 * 1024 * 15) overflow during arithmetic operations on 32-bit systems or when combined with other size calculations, bypassing intended limits? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: MESSAGE_SIZE_LIMIT] [Fragmentation Attack] Can an attacker exploit the MESSAGE_SIZE_LIMIT by sending maximum-size messages with fragmented data structures that cause excessive parsing overhead, CPU exhaustion, or algorithmic complexity attacks? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-utils/src/constants.rs] [Constant: MESSAGE_SIZE_LIMIT] [Buffer Allocation DoS] Does MESSAGE_SIZE_LIMIT enforcement occur before or after buffer allocation? Can attackers force pre-allocation of 15MB buffers even for smaller messages, multiplying memory consumption? (Medium)
